title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Form validation requires proper attributes. Explain the relationship between HTML5 required and ARIA aria-required attributes.
explanation: HTML5 'required' provides both validation and accessibility (screen readers announce as required). 'aria-required' is redundant when 'required' is present. Use 'required' for native validation and accessibility. Only use 'aria-required' when you can't use 'required' (custom validation, progressive enhancement).

options.text: HTML5 'required' provides both validation and accessibility (screen readers announce as required).
options.explanation: Correct. HTML5 'required' provides both validation and accessibility (screen readers announce as required). 'aria-required' is redundant when 'required' is present. Use 'required' for native validation and accessibility. Only use 'aria-required' when you can't use 'required' (custom validation, progressive enhancement).

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Form accessibility requires proper labeling. Explain how aria-describedby and aria-labelledby provide different types of information to screen readers.
explanation: 'aria-labelledby' provides primary label (what is this field). 'aria-describedby' provides additional description (help text, error messages, hints). Label is announced first, description after. Use labelledby for field name, describedby for instructions or errors. Both can reference multiple IDs.

options.text: 'aria-labelledby' provides primary label (what is this field).
options.explanation: Correct. 'aria-labelledby' provides primary label (what is this field). 'aria-describedby' provides additional description (help text, error messages, hints). Label is announced first, description after. Use labelledby for field name, describedby for instructions or errors. Both can reference multiple IDs.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: ARIA attributes control screen reader behavior. Explain how aria-hidden and aria-live affect accessibility announcements.
explanation: 'aria-hidden=true' hides element from screen readers (decorative content). 'aria-live' announces dynamic content changes ('polite' waits, 'assertive' interrupts). Use aria-hidden for icons, decorative images. Use aria-live for dynamic updates (form errors, notifications). Be careful not to hide important content.

options.text: 'aria-hidden=true' hides element from screen readers (decorative content).
options.explanation: Correct. 'aria-hidden=true' hides element from screen readers (decorative content). 'aria-live' announces dynamic content changes ('polite' waits, 'assertive' interrupts). Use aria-hidden for icons, decorative images. Use aria-live for dynamic updates (form errors, notifications). Be careful not to hide important content.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Title tags are crucial for SEO. Explain the relationship between <titl, <h1, and search engine optimization.
explanation: <titl appears in browser tab and search results (50-60 chars optimal). <h1 is main page heading (visible on page). Both should be relevant but can differ. Title is for SEO and browser tab. H1 is for page structure and accessibility. Both important but serve different purposes.

options.text: <titl appears in browser tab and search results (50-60 chars optimal).
options.explanation: Correct. <title> appears in browser tab and search results (50-60 chars optimal). <h1> is main page heading (visible on page). Both should be relevant but can differ. Title is for SEO and browser tab. H1 is for page structure and accessibility. Both important but serve different purposes.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Structured data helps search engines understand content. Explain the different formats and their SEO benefits.
explanation: Structured data (Schema.org) helps search engines understand content type (Article, Product, Review, etc.). Formats: JSON-LD (recommended, in <script), Microdata (attributes), RDFa (attributes). Enables rich snippets (ratings, prices, dates). JSON-LD is cleanest, doesn't mix with HTML. Improves search visibility.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Duplicate content hurts SEO. Explain canonical tags and how they tell search engines which URL is the preferred version.
explanation: Canonical tag specifies preferred URL when multiple URLs show same content (www vs non-www, HTTP vs HTTPS, parameters). Prevents duplicate content penalties, consolidates ranking signals. Use absolute URLs. Important for e-commerce (filtered product pages) and multi-domain setups.

options.text: Canonical tag specifies preferred URL when multiple URLs show same content (www vs non-www, HTTP vs HTTPS, parameters).

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Controlling search engine behavior requires meta tags. Explain robots directives and when to use them.
explanation: 'noindex' prevents page from appearing in search results. 'nofollow' tells crawlers not to follow links on page. 'noindex, nofollow' for private/admin pages. Use on duplicate content, staging sites, or pages you don't want indexed. Can also use X-Robots-Tag HTTP header.

options.text: 'noindex' prevents page from appearing in search results.

Use on duplicate content, staging sites, or pages you don't want indexed. Can also use X-Robots-Tag HTTP header.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Heading structure matters for SEO and accessibility. Explain proper heading hierarchy and its impact on search rankings.
explanation: Headings create document outline: <h1 is main title (one per page), <h2 sections, <h3 subsections, etc. Proper hierarchy helps search engines understand content structure. Improves SEO and accessibility. Don't skip levels (h1 to h3). Use headings semantically, not for styling.

options.text: Headings create document outline: <h1 is main title (one per page), <h2 sections, <h3 subsections, etc.

Improves SEO and accessibility. Don't skip levels (h1 to h3). Use headings semantically, not for styling.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Search result snippets can be controlled. Explain robots meta tag snippet controls and their SEO implications.
explanation: Snippet controls limit how search engines display your content: 'max-snippet' (character limit), 'max-image-preview' (image size), 'max-video-preview' (video length). Helps control how your content appears in search results. Useful for protecting content or optimizing CTR.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: ARIA landmarks help screen readers understand page structure. Explain the main landmark roles and their semantic equivalents.
explanation: ARIA landmarks define page regions: 'banner' (header), 'main' (main content), 'navigation' (nav), 'complementary' (aside), 'contentinfo' (footer), 'search' (search area). Screen readers can jump between landmarks. Prefer semantic HTML (<header, <main, <nav) but use ARIA when semantic elements aren't available.

options.text: ARIA landmarks define page regions: 'banner' (header), 'main' (main content), 'navigation' (nav), 'complementary' (aside), 'contentinfo' (footer), 'search' (search area).
options.explanation: Correct. Screen readers can jump between landmarks. Prefer semantic HTML (<header>, <main>, <nav>) but use ARIA when semantic elements aren't available.

content: ARIA labeling provides accessible names. Explain the differences between aria-label and aria-labelledby and their use cases.
explanation: 'aria-label' provides direct text label. 'aria-labelledby' references ID of element containing label text. Use 'aria-label' for simple labels when visible text isn't sufficient. Use 'aria-labelledby' when label text exists elsewhere in DOM (reuses existing text, maintains single source of truth).

content: Author attribution affects SEO and rich snippets. Compare meta author tag vs structured data (Person/Author schema) for SEO benefits.
explanation: Meta author tag is simple but limited. Structured data (Person/Author schema) provides rich information (name, image, social profiles) and enables author rich snippets in search results. Structured data is preferred for SEO as it provides more context to search engines and better search result appearance.

content: Audio elements have various playback controls. Explain the key attributes and their accessibility implications.
explanation: 'controls' shows play/pause/volume UI. 'autoplay' starts automatically (often blocked by browsers). 'loop' repeats audio. 'preload' controls download behavior. Always include 'controls' for accessibility. Avoid autoplay (annoying, blocked). Provide text alternative for audio content.

content: Video thumbnails enhance UX. Explain the poster attribute and its role in video presentation.
explanation: 'poster' attribute specifies image URL shown before video plays. Provides visual preview, improves perceived performance, gives context. Should be representative frame from video. Falls back to first frame if not provided. Important for video galleries and previews.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Image accessibility requires proper attributes. Explain alt vs title attributes and their different purposes for accessibility and UX.
explanation: 'alt' provides text alternative for screen readers and when image fails to load. Required for accessibility. 'title' provides tooltip on hover (not read by screen readers). Use 'alt' for meaningful images (describe content), empty alt='' for decorative images. Use 'title' sparingly for additional context.

options.text: 'alt' provides text alternative for screen readers and when image fails to load.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Video loading behavior affects performance and user experience. Explain autoplay vs preload and when each is appropriate.
explanation: 'autoplay' starts video automatically (requires 'muted' in most browsers). 'preload' hints how much to download: 'none' (don't preload), 'metadata' (dimensions, duration), 'auto' (entire video). Autoplay can annoy users and waste bandwidth. Preload='metadata' is good balance. Use autoplay sparingly with muted videos.

options.text: 'autoplay' starts video automatically (requires 'muted' in most browsers).
options.explanation: Correct. 'autoplay' starts video automatically (requires 'muted' in most browsers). 'preload' hints how much to download: 'none' (don't preload), 'metadata' (dimensions, duration), 'auto' (entire video). Autoplay can annoy users and waste bandwidth. Preload='metadata' is good balance. Use autoplay sparingly with muted videos.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Responsive images require proper srcset configuration. Explain how srcset and sizes work together to serve appropriate images.
explanation: 'srcset' provides multiple image sources with descriptors (width: 800w, pixel density: 2x). 'sizes' tells browser viewport width for image (e.g., '(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 50vw'). Browser selects best image based on device pixel ratio and viewport. Essential for responsive design performance.

content: Mobile video behavior differs from desktop. Explain playsinline and its impact on iOS Safari and other mobile browsers.
explanation: 'playsinline' prevents iOS Safari from entering fullscreen when video plays. Without it, video opens in fullscreen player. Essential for inline video playback in web pages on iOS. Also affects Android browsers. Use with autoplay for seamless mobile video experience.

content: Media embedding has multiple approaches. Explain when to use iframe (YouTube, Vimeo) vs native video/audio elements.
explanation: <ifram embeds external player (YouTube, Vimeo) - provides features, handles hosting, but less control. <video/<audio are native HTML5 players - full control, better performance, but you host files. Use iframe for third-party services. Use native elements for self-hosted media with custom controls.

content: Understanding form control grouping. Explain how radio buttons and checkboxes differ, and how the name attribute creates groups.
explanation: Radio buttons: single selection per group (same name), mutually exclusive. Checkboxes: multiple selections allowed, independent. Radio groups share 'name' attribute. Checkboxes can share name (array values) or be independent. Use radio for mutually exclusive options, checkbox for multiple selections.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Form grouping is important for accessibility. Explain how fieldset and legend help screen readers and keyboard navigation.
explanation: <fieldset groups related form controls. <legend provides label for the group. Screen readers announce legend before each field in group. Improves form comprehension, especially for complex forms. Required for radio button groups. Helps keyboard navigation.

options.text: <fieldset groups related form controls.
options.explanation: Correct. <fieldset> groups related form controls. <legend> provides label for the group. Screen readers announce legend before each field in group. Improves form comprehension, especially for complex forms. Required for radio button groups. Helps keyboard navigation.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Input types affect validation and user experience. Compare email input type vs text with pattern, including mobile keyboard and accessibility differences.
explanation: type='email' provides native validation, mobile keyboard (@ symbol), and semantic meaning. pattern on text requires manual regex. Email type is more accessible (screen readers announce as email field). Use email type for email addresses, pattern for custom formats.

options.text: type='email' provides native validation, mobile keyboard (@ symbol), and semantic meaning.
options.explanation: Correct. type='email' provides native validation, mobile keyboard (@ symbol), and semantic meaning. pattern on text requires manual regex. Email type is more accessible (screen readers announce as email field). Use email type for email addresses, pattern for custom formats.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Performance optimization for images. Explain the 'loading' attribute values and their impact on page load performance.
explanation: 'loading' attribute controls when image loads: 'lazy' defers loading until near viewport, 'eager' loads immediately. Lazy loading reduces initial page load, saves bandwidth, improves LCP. Use 'lazy' for below-fold images, 'eager' for above-fold critical images. Browser support is good in modern browsers.

options.text: 'loading' attribute controls when image loads: 'lazy' defers loading until near viewport, 'eager' loads immediately.
options.explanation: Correct. 'loading' attribute controls when image loads: 'lazy' defers loading until near viewport, 'eager' loads immediately. Lazy loading reduces initial page load, saves bandwidth, improves LCP. Use 'lazy' for below-fold images, 'eager' for above-fold critical images. Browser support is good in modern browsers.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Browser autocomplete can enhance user experience. Explain the autocomplete attribute values and their impact on form filling.
explanation: 'autocomplete' hints browser what data to suggest (name, email, address, etc.). Values like 'name', 'email', 'tel', 'address-line1', 'cc-number', 'current-password'. Improves UX, reduces errors, speeds up form completion. Use 'off' to disable, 'new-password' for password managers.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Security is critical for forms. Explain Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) attacks and how HTML form attributes help prevent them.
explanation: CSRF tricks users into submitting forms to attacker's site. Protection: hidden CSRF tokens (server validates), SameSite cookie attribute (Strict/Lax prevents cross-site sends), referrer checking. HTML alone can't fully prevent CSRF; need server-side validation. SameSite='Strict' is strongest protection.

options.text: CSRF tricks users into submitting forms to attacker's site.
options.explanation: Correct. CSRF tricks users into submitting forms to attacker's site. Protection: hidden CSRF tokens (server validates), SameSite cookie attribute (Strict/Lax prevents cross-site sends), referrer checking. HTML alone can't fully prevent CSRF; need server-side validation. SameSite='Strict' is strongest protection.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Modern HTML5 allows inputs outside forms. Explain the 'form' attribute and its use cases for complex form layouts.
explanation: 'form' attribute links input to form by form's id, even if input is outside <form tag. Enables flexible layouts (inputs in different DOM locations), multiple forms sharing inputs, or inputs in modals/dialogs. Input participates in form validation and submission.

options.text: 'form' attribute links input to form by form's id, even if input is outside <form tag.
options.explanation: Correct. 'form' attribute links input to form by form's id, even if input is outside <form> tag. Enables flexible layouts (inputs in different DOM locations), multiple forms sharing inputs, or inputs in modals/dialogs. Input participates in form validation and submission.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Form submission buttons have different implementations. Explain the differences and accessibility implications of input vs button elements.
explanation: <input type='submit'> only allows text content. <button type='submit'> allows HTML content (icons, formatting). Button is more flexible for styling and content. Both submit forms identically. Button is generally preferred for modern development due to flexibility.

options.text: <input type='submit'> only allows text content.
options.explanation: Correct. <input type='submit'> only allows text content. <button type='submit'> allows HTML content (icons, formatting). Button is more flexible for styling and content. Both submit forms identically. Button is generally preferred for modern development due to flexibility.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: URL resolution matters for security and performance. When should you use absolute vs relative URLs, and what are the risks?
explanation: Absolute URLs include protocol and domain (https://example.com/page). Relative URLs are resolved from current page location (/page, ../page). Absolute URLs prevent protocol-relative issues but are verbose. Relative URLs are shorter but can break with base tag changes. Use absolute for external, relative for internal.

options.text: Absolute URLs include protocol and domain (https://example.
options.explanation: Correct. Absolute URLs include protocol and domain (https://example.com/page). Relative URLs are resolved from current page location (/page, ../page). Absolute URLs prevent protocol-relative issues but are verbose. Relative URLs are shorter but can break with base tag changes. Use absolute for external, relative for internal.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Senior developers need to understand document type declarations. Explain DOCTYPE's role in rendering mode and browser compatibility.
explanation: DOCTYPE tells the browser which HTML version to use, triggering standards mode vs quirks mode. Missing/incorrect DOCTYPE causes quirks mode: inconsistent rendering, box model issues, layout bugs. Always use <!DOCTYPE html for HTML5.

options.text: DOCTYPE tells the browser which HTML version to use, triggering standards mode vs quirks mode.
options.explanation: Correct. DOCTYPE tells the browser which HTML version to use, triggering standards mode vs quirks mode. Missing/incorrect DOCTYPE causes quirks mode: inconsistent rendering, box model issues, layout bugs. Always use <!DOCTYPE html> for HTML5.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: The <bas tag affects URL resolution. Explain its purpose and the common issues developers encounter with it.
explanation: <bas sets base URL for all relative URLs on page. Affects href, src, form actions. Pitfalls: breaks anchors (#section), affects all relative URLs (can't override), can cause security issues if user-controlled. Use sparingly, prefer absolute URLs for external resources.

options.text: <bas sets base URL for all relative URLs on page.
options.explanation: Correct. <base> sets base URL for all relative URLs on page. Affects href, src, form actions. Pitfalls: breaks anchors (#section), affects all relative URLs (can't override), can cause security issues if user-controlled. Use sparingly, prefer absolute URLs for external resources.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Code display requires specific elements. Explain when to use <pr, <cod, or both together, and their semantic differences.
explanation: e is inline element for code snippets (variable names, functions). <pre is block element preserving whitespace and line breaks. Use <pree together for code blocks. <cod alone for inline code. <pr alone for formatted text (ASCII art, poetry).

options.text: <cod is inline element for code snippets (variable names, functions).
options.explanation: Correct. <code> is inline element for code snippets (variable names, functions). <pre> is block element preserving whitespace and line breaks. Use <pre><code> together for code blocks. <code> alone for inline code. <pre> alone for formatted text (ASCII art, poetry).

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Definition lists are underused semantic elements. Explain their purpose and when they're more appropriate than <ul or custom structures.
explanation: <dl is definition list container. <dt is term/name. <dd is definition/description. Use for key-value pairs, glossaries, metadata, FAQ structures. More semantic than <ul for term-definition relationships. Screen readers announce relationships between terms and definitions.

options.text: <dl is definition list container.
options.explanation: Correct. <dl> is definition list container. <dt> is term/name. <dd> is definition/description. Use for key-value pairs, glossaries, metadata, FAQ structures. More semantic than <ul> for term-definition relationships. Screen readers announce relationships between terms and definitions.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Understanding generic containers vs semantic elements. When is it acceptable to use <div/<span, and when should you prefer semantic HTML5 elements?
explanation: <div is block-level generic container. <span is inline generic container. Both are non-semantic. Prefer semantic elements (<header, <nav, <main, <articl, <section, <footer) when they match content meaning. Use <div/<span only when no semantic element fits.

options.text: <div is block-level generic container.
options.explanation: Correct. <div> is block-level generic container. <span> is inline generic container. Both are non-semantic. Prefer semantic elements (<header>, <nav>, <main>, <article>, <section>, <footer>) when they match content meaning. Use <div>/<span> only when no semantic element fits.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Text emphasis tags have semantic meaning. Explain the differences and accessibility implications of these tags.
explanation: <b and <i are presentational (bold, italic) with no semantic meaning. <strong and <em are semantic (importance, emphasis) and also styled bold/italic. Use <strong for important text, <em for emphasis. Avoid <b/<i unless purely decorative. Screen readers interpret semantic tags differently.

options.text: <b and <i are presentational (bold, italic) with no semantic meaning.
options.explanation: Correct. <b> and <i> are presentational (bold, italic) with no semantic meaning. <strong> and <em> are semantic (importance, emphasis) and also styled bold/italic. Use <strong> for important text, <em> for emphasis. Avoid <b>/<i> unless purely decorative. Screen readers interpret semantic tags differently.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Understanding attribute purposes. Explain when to use 'id' vs 'name', especially in forms and JavaScript targeting.
explanation: 'id' is unique identifier for single element (CSS, JS targeting, anchors). 'name' is for form controls, groups radio buttons, used in form submission. 'id' must be unique per page. 'name' can be shared (radio groups). Use 'id' for targeting, 'name' for form data.

options.text: 'id' is unique identifier for single element (CSS, JS targeting, anchors).
options.explanation: Correct. 'id' is unique identifier for single element (CSS, JS targeting, anchors). 'name' is for form controls, groups radio buttons, used in form submission. 'id' must be unique per page. 'name' can be shared (radio groups). Use 'id' for targeting, 'name' for form data.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Senior developers must understand HTTP methods. Explain the differences between GET and POST, including security, caching, and use case implications.
explanation: GET sends data in URL (visible, bookmarkable, cached). POST sends data in body (hidden, not cached, no length limit). Use GET for idempotent operations (search, filters). Use POST for state changes (create, update, delete). GET is less secure for sensitive data.

options.text: GET sends data in URL (visible, bookmarkable, cached).
options.explanation: Correct. GET sends data in URL (visible, bookmarkable, cached). POST sends data in body (hidden, not cached, no length limit). Use GET for idempotent operations (search, filters). Use POST for state changes (create, update, delete). GET is less secure for sensitive data.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: HTML5 provides native validation. Explain how validation attributes work, their limitations, and when you still need JavaScript validation.
explanation: 'required' makes field mandatory. 'pattern' validates against regex. 'min'/'max' set numeric/date ranges. 'type' (email, url, number) provides built-in validation. Browser shows native error messages. Still need server-side validation (client-side can be bypassed).

options.text: 'required' makes field mandatory.
options.explanation: Correct. 'required' makes field mandatory. 'pattern' validates against regex. 'min'/'max' set numeric/date ranges. 'type' (email, url, number) provides built-in validation. Browser shows native error messages. Still need server-side validation (client-side can be bypassed).

title: 'async' and 'defer' are identical in behavior, just different syntax
content: As a senior developer optimizing page load performance, explain the differences between defer, async, and neither attribute on script tags, including execution order and DOM readiness.
explanation: Without attributes: script blocks HTML parsing. 'async': downloads in parallel, executes immediately when ready (order not guaranteed). 'defer': downloads in parallel, executes after HTML parsing completes, in document order. Use 'async' for independent scripts (analytics). Use 'defer' for scripts that depend on DOM or need execution order.

options.text: 'async' executes as soon as downloaded (order not guaranteed); 'defer' executes after HTML parsing in document order
options.explanation: Correct. 'async' prioritizes speed but loses execution order. 'defer' maintains order and waits for DOM.

options.text: Both 'async' and 'defer' execute scripts in the same order they appear in the document
options.explanation: Incorrect. 'async' scripts execute as soon as they're downloaded, which may not match document order.

options.text: 'defer' blocks HTML parsing, 'async' does not
options.explanation: Incorrect. Both allow parallel downloading. Neither blocks parsing, but scripts without attributes do block parsing.

options.text: 'async' and 'defer' are identical in behavior, just different syntax
options.explanation: Incorrect. They have fundamentally different execution timing and ordering guarantees.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Understanding character encoding is crucial. When should you use named entities vs numeric character references, and what are the encoding implications?
explanation: Named entities (&, <) are readable and common. Numeric references (A decimal, A hex) work for any Unicode character. Use entities for special characters (<, >, &, quotes). Use numeric for rare Unicode or when entity names aren't available.

options.text: Named entities (&, <) are readable and common.
options.explanation: Correct. Named entities (&, <) are readable and common. Numeric references (A decimal, A hex) work for any Unicode character. Use entities for special characters (<, >, &, quotes). Use numeric for rare Unicode or when entity names aren't available.

title: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
content: Senior developers must understand CSS box model implications. How do block, inline, and inline-block elements differ in terms of width, height, margins, and layout?
explanation: Block elements take full width, start on new line, respect width/height. Inline elements flow within text, ignore width/height, only respect horizontal margins. Inline-block combines both: flows inline but respects width/height like block elements.

options.text: Block elements take full width, start on new line, respect width/height.
options.explanation: Correct. Block elements take full width, start on new line, respect width/height. Inline elements flow within text, ignore width/height, only respect horizontal margins. Inline-block combines both: flows inline but respects width/height like block elements.

options.text: All options are equivalent and can be used interchangeably
options.explanation: Incorrect. There are important semantic and functional differences.

options.text: The differences are only visual and don't affect functionality
options.explanation: Incorrect. These differences affect semantics, accessibility, and behavior.

options.text: Modern browsers handle all cases identically regardless of choice
options.explanation: Incorrect. Browser behavior and accessibility features differ based on element choice.

title: Native elements and ARIA roles are equivalent, choose based on team preference
content: A senior developer must understand accessibility. When should you use ARIA roles (role='button', role='navigation') vs native semantic elements (<button, <nav)? What are the implications?
explanation: Always prefer native semantic HTML elements (<button, <nav, <main) over ARIA roles because native elements provide built-in keyboard support, focus management, and browser behavior. Use ARIA roles only when native elements cannot achieve the desired interaction pattern (e.g., complex widgets, custom components). ARIA should enhance, not replace, semantic HTML.

options.text: Prefer native semantic elements; use ARIA only when native elements cannot achieve the interaction pattern
options.explanation: Correct. Native elements provide built-in accessibility features. ARIA is a fallback for custom components.

options.text: ARIA roles are always better because they're more explicit and modern
options.explanation: Incorrect. ARIA should complement, not replace, semantic HTML. Native elements provide more built-in functionality.

options.text: Use ARIA roles on all interactive elements for better screen reader support
options.explanation: Incorrect. Redundant ARIA on native elements can actually confuse screen readers. Use ARIA only when necessary.

options.text: Native elements and ARIA roles are equivalent, choose based on team preference
options.explanation: Incorrect. Native elements provide keyboard support, focus management, and browser behavior that ARIA alone cannot replicate.

title: <articl is for blog posts only, <section is for everything else
content: A senior developer needs to understand semantic HTML5 elements. When would you use <articl vs <section, and what are the accessibility implications?
explanation: <articl represents independent, self-contained content that could be distributed (like blog posts, news articles). <section represents a thematic grouping of content, typically with a heading. Articles can contain sections, and sections can contain articles. Use <articl for standalone content, <section for organizing related content.

options.text: <articl is for standalone content that makes sense independently; <section is for thematic grouping of related content
options.explanation: Correct. <article> should be independently distributable, while <section> groups related content thematically.

options.text: <articl and <section are interchangeable and can be used based on personal preference
options.explanation: Incorrect. They have distinct semantic meanings that affect accessibility and SEO.

options.text: <section is always nested inside <articl, never the reverse
options.explanation: Incorrect. Articles can contain sections, and sections can contain articles depending on the content structure.

options.text: <articl is for blog posts only, <section is for everything else
options.explanation: Incorrect. <article> can represent any standalone content (forum posts, comments, widgets, etc.), not just blog posts.

title: <templat automatically renders its content on page load
content: Modern HTML5 features for senior developers. What is the <templat element, how does the browser handle it, and what are the performance implications?
explanation: <templat content is inert (not rendered, scripts don't run, images don't load) until cloned via JavaScript. Hidden <div elements are still parsed, can trigger resource loading, and are part of the DOM. Use <templat for client-side templating, reusable component structures, or when you need truly inert content that won't affect page load.

options.text: <templat content is inert until cloned; hidden <div is still parsed and can load resources
options.explanation: Correct. <template> is truly inert, while hidden elements are still processed by the browser.

options.text: <templat and hidden <div behave identically
options.explanation: Incorrect. <template> is inert and doesn't trigger resource loading or script execution until cloned.

options.text: Hidden <div is better for performance because it's simpler
options.explanation: Incorrect. Hidden divs still consume resources during parsing. <template> is more efficient for unused content.

options.text: <templat automatically renders its content on page load
options.explanation: Incorrect. <template> content is inert and never renders automatically. It must be cloned via JavaScript.

title: CSP is only needed for sites with user-generated content
content: Security is critical for senior developers. How does CSP work, what directives are most important, and how does it prevent XSS?
explanation: CSP restricts which resources (scripts, styles, images) can be loaded and executed, preventing XSS by blocking inline scripts and unauthorized sources. Key directives: default-src (fallback), script-src (JavaScript sources), style-src (CSS sources), img-src (images), connect-src (AJAX/fetch). 'unsafe-inline' and 'unsafe-eval' should be avoided when possible.

options.text: CSP restricts resource loading sources, preventing XSS by blocking unauthorized scripts/styles. Key directives: default-src, script-src, style-src
options.explanation: Correct. CSP is a security mechanism that whitelists allowed sources for resources, preventing injection attacks.

options.text: CSP only prevents clickjacking, not XSS attacks
options.explanation: Incorrect. CSP primarily prevents XSS by controlling script execution. X-Frame-Options prevents clickjacking.

options.text: CSP allows all inline scripts by default for convenience
options.explanation: Incorrect. CSP blocks inline scripts by default. 'unsafe-inline' must be explicitly added, but it reduces security.

options.text: CSP is only needed for sites with user-generated content
options.explanation: Incorrect. CSP should be used on all sites as defense-in-depth, not just sites with user content.
